item.title: Credential hunting with gitleaks
item.description: Credential hunting is relevant to anyone in the infosec/cybersecurity space. I’ll spare you the long and probably unneeed introduction you get on most blogs and websites. Let’s just say that if you commit login credentials to your code or data repositories in plaintext, it is only a matter of time before they are found by malicious actors and used against you. So… what to do? Under the assumption there may already be credentials from the past in your repositories and sometime in the future some might accidentally get commited, the thing to do is scan for them on a regular basis.

item.title: Threat hunting with splunk: sorting by IP
item.description: Following up on a previous post on splunk and threat hunting, let’s go a step further. We demonstrated a query to show us attempted logins against joomla admin page. We saw what the attempted credentials were, but this resulted in so many lines of output that we couldn’t easily compile a list of IPs that we could identify as malicious. Here is the original query we talked about: index=botsv1 earliest=0 http_method=POST uri="/joomla/administrator/index.

item.title: Threat hunting with splunk: simple credential attacks
item.description: Over in my useful_snippets repo, I just added a neat little example: index=botsv1 earliest=0 http_method=POST uri="/joomla/administrator/index.php" site="imreallynotbatman.com" src_ip="23.22.63.114" | table timestamp,form_data It uses the botsv1 example dataset (provided by splunk), searches the entire history of the dataset for specified URL and sie. It then creates a table with timestamp and the form data as passed in by the browser. This is an example, but you can build off it to manually inspect what users and passwords are being targetted by malicious actors.

item.title: Vulnerability Management Programs
item.description: Why VM Program The components of a VM Program Tools A critical component of keeping your environment safe from exploitation is knowing what vulnerabilities exist, prioritising them for remediation and managing that process. That can look different from org to org based on a variety of factors to numerous go into here. Suffice it say there is no one good solution and teams will have to pick and choose the components of a vulnerability management program that works for them.
